answer_html: Hence \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is continuous everywhere and thus there are no vertical asymptotes.
answer_latex:
Hence $\displaystyle f(x)$ is
continuous everywhere and thus there are no vertical asymptotes.
hints_html: Recall that \(\displaystyle a\) is a candidate for a vertical asymptote only if \(\displaystyle f(x)\) has a discontinuity at \(\displaystyle a\), so that there is a chance that \(\displaystyle f(x)\) tends to \(\displaystyle \infty\) or \(\displaystyle -\infty\) as \(\displaystyle x\) approaches \(\displaystyle a\).
hints_latex:
Recall that $\displaystyle a$ is a candidate for a vertical asymptote
only if $\displaystyle f(x)$ has a discontinuity at $\displaystyle a$,
so that there is a chance that $\displaystyle f(x)$ tends to
$\displaystyle \infty$ or $\displaystyle -\infty$ as $\displaystyle x$
approaches $\displaystyle a$.
hints_raw: Recall that <math>\displaystyle a</math> is a candidate for a vertical asymptote only if <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> has a discontinuity at <math>\displaystyle a</math>, so that there is a chance that <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> tends to <math>\displaystyle \infty</math> or <math>\displaystyle -\infty</math> as <math> \displaystyle x</math> approaches <math>\displaystyle a</math>.
question: 3 (b)
sols_html: The functions \(\displaystyle \sin(x)\) and \(\displaystyle e^x\) are both continuous everywhere. Further, the function in the denominator, \(\displaystyle e^x\), is never 0. Hence \(\displaystyle f(x)\) is continuous everywhere and thus there are no vertical asymptotes.
sols_latex:
The functions $\displaystyle \sin(x)$ and $\displaystyle e^x$ are both
continuous everywhere. Further, the function in the denominator,
$\displaystyle e^x$, is never 0. Hence $\displaystyle f(x)$ is
continuous everywhere and thus there are no vertical asymptotes.
sols_raw: The functions <math>\displaystyle \sin(x)</math> and <math>\displaystyle e^x</math> are both continuous everywhere. Further, the function in the denominator, <math>\displaystyle e^x</math>, is never 0. Hence <math>\displaystyle f(x)</math> is continuous everywhere and thus there are no vertical asymptotes.
statement_html:
Let \(f(x) = \frac{\sin(x)}{e^{x}}\) on the interval \([0, \pi]\). In this question you will sketch this function.

(b) Find the vertical asymptotes of \(f\), if any exist.
statement_latex:
Let $f(x) = \frac{\sin(x)}{e^{x}}$ on the interval $[0, \pi]$. In this
question you will sketch this function.

\textbf{(b)} Find the vertical asymptotes of $f$, if any exist.
